block.p: Greening Brooklyn

Greening Brooklyn.
Greening Brooklyn
Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue (Eastern Parkway), Prospect Heights; (718)623-7200.

''Making Brooklyn Bloom,'' lectures and discussions about planning community gardens, will take place from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. on Saturday. Topics will include selecting vegetables for a garden, rainwater harvesting, how to involve young people in a neighborhood garden, and seed propagation. There will also be exhibits and free guided tours.
A Mobile Ceramic Feast
Museum of Arts and Design, 40 West 53rd Street; (212)956-3535.

The museum will offer ''Functional Pottery: Exploring the Domestic Landscape,'' an exhibition housed in an Airstream travel trailer, from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. on Monday. The exhibition features vases, tea sets, plates and mugs by 20 contemporary potters. The trailer is traveling through New York on its way to Baltimore. Free.
Antiques on Park
Seventh Regiment Armory, 643 Park Avenue (66th Street); (212)472-1180.

The New York Armory and Antiques and Design Show, featuring furniture, jewelry, paintings, textiles, clocks and books for sale by 60 dealers, will be open today and tomorrow, 11 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Saturday, 11 a.m. to 7:30 p.m.; and Sunday, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission is $10.
Rugs by Hand
American Folk Art Museum, 45 West 53rd Street; (212)265-1040.

The annual rug hooking weekend will take place tomorrow and Saturday, from 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. Events include demonstrations by members of area rug-hooking guilds (Saturday, from 11 a.m. to 4 p.m.); a lecture on works inspired by playing cards, by Linda Rae Coughlin, the artist who organized the deck of cards project (Saturday, 12:30 p.m.); and gallery tours of textiles in the permanent collection and in ''Ancestry and Innovation: African American Art From the Collection'' (at 11 a.m. and 2 p.m. each day). Free with museum admission, which is $9; students and those 65 and older, $7.

There will also be two workshops during the weekend: tomorrow from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m., participants will hook a small pillow-size mat in blue yarns (the fee is $95 plus a materials fee of $40); on Saturday, from 9 a.m. to noon, participants will make an octagonal shoulder bag (fee, $45 plus a materials fee of $40). Reservations are required.

''Ancestry and Innovation,'' an exhibition of African-American folk art that includes paintings, sculpture and quilts, will be at the museum through Sept. 4. A series of gallery tours, from noon to 1 p.m., each free with admission, will focus on contemporary works (today, May 5 and June 2) or quilts (March 31, May 5 and June 16).

On May 20 at 6 p.m., there will be a lecture on the use of African patterns and symbols in quilts by African-Americans. The speaker will be Myrah Brown Green of the New York chapter of the Women of Color Quilters Network. Tickets are $5; students and those 65 and older, free.
The museum is open Tuesday through Sunday, 10:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. (until 7:30 p.m. on Fridays).
Roses
Horticultural Society of New York, 128 West 58th Street; (516)759-1435.
The Manhattan Rose Society will offer a talk by Joyce Fleming, a rose grower, at 6:30 p.m. today. Admission is $10; members, free.
Japanese Design
Japan Society, 333 East 47th Street; (212)752-3015.

The society and the Museum of Arts and Design will sponsor ''New Design Japan,'' a two-day symposium. The event opens on March 18 at 6:30 p.m. with a discussion between Teruo Kurosaki, a Tokyo designer, and Karim Rashid, the architect and designer.

A series of panel discussions will take place on March 19, from 10 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. Participants will include Yoshiki Hishinuma, a fashion designer; Toshiko Mori, an architect; Tsutomu Kurokawa, an interior designer; Matilda McQuaid, head of the textiles department at the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum; and Paola Antonelli, a curator in the architecture and design department at the Museum of Modern Art.

Reservations are suggested. Tickets for the symposium are $85; students, $50; members and those 65 and older, $75; for Friday only, $25; students, $20; members and those 65 and older, $15; for Saturday only, $75; students, $45; members and those 65 and older, $60.
